quest_title: A body of mass '\(\text{m}\)' is pulled by a rope which makes an angle \(\theta\) with horizontal. If \(\text{\(\mu\) }\) be the coefficient of friction between the body and ground then the tension on the rope to make the body just to move is
explanation_txt:
\(T \cos \theta=\mu m g-\mu T \cos \theta\)
\(\therefore T=\cfrac{\mu m g}{\cos \theta+\mu \sin \theta}\)

quest_title: Capillary tube of radius r can support a liquid of weight 6.28\(\times\)10\({}^{-4}\)N. If surface tension of liquid is 5\(\times\)10\({}^{-2}\)N/m then radius of capillary tube is
explanation_txt:
\(\mathrm{wt}=\cfrac{2 T}{r} A\)
\(\mathrm{wt}=\cfrac{2 T}{r} \times \pi r^{2}\)

\(\therefore r=\cfrac{w t}{2 \pi T}=\cfrac{6.28 \times 10^{-4}}{2 \pi \times 5 \times 10^{-2}}=2\times 10^{-3} \, m\)
question_plain_title: Capillary tube of radius r can support a liquid of weight 6.2810N. If surface tension of liquid is 510N/m then radius of capillary tube is
ans1_plain_text: 2.510m
ans2_plain_text: 1.510m
ans3_plain_text: 210m
ans4_plain_text: 210m

quest_title: At what temperature reading on celcius scale will be half the reading on Fahrenheit scale.
explanation_txt: \(\begin{array}{l}{\mathrm{F}=\mathrm{x} \quad \mathrm{C}=\mathrm{x} / 2} \\ {\cfrac{C}{100}=\cfrac{F-32}{180}} \\ {\cfrac{x}{10}=\cfrac{x-32}{9}} \\ {\mathrm{x}=320^{\circ} \mathrm{F} \text { or } \mathrm{x} / 2=160^{\circ} \mathrm{C}}\end{array}\)

quest_title: If a liquid is heated in weightlessness, the heat is transmitted through
ans4_txt: Neither, because the liquid cannot be heated in weightlessness
explanation_txt:
Convection is the heat transfer due to the bulk movement of molecules within fluids. The movement is because forces of gravity is higher in denser fluid which is cold and lesser in lighter fluid which is hot.

Weightlessness is the absence of force of gravity. Therefore, convection is not possible in weightlessness. So the liquid will be heated through conduction.
question_plain_title: If a liquid is heated in weightlessness, the heat is transmitted through
explanation_plain_text:
Convection is the heat transfer due to the bulk movement of molecules within fluids. The movement is because forces of gravity is higher in denser fluid which is cold and lesser in lighter fluid which is hot.

Weightlessness is the absence of force of gravity. Therefore, convection is not possible in weightlessness. So the liquid will be heated through conduction.
ans4_plain_text: Neither, because the liquid cannot be heated in weightlessness

quest_title: Light from sodium lamp is passed through cold sodium vapours, the spectrum of transmitted light consists of
explanation_txt: Kirchhoff's law of absorption states a substance in unexcited state will absorb those wavelength which it emits in de-excitation. So, sodium vapours absorb the light produced by sodium lamp and hence, no spectral feature is produced.

quest_title: In Young's double slit experiment, if L is the distance between the slits and the screen upon which interference pattern is observed, x is the average distance between the adjacent fringes and d being the slit separation. The wavelength of light is given by
explanation_txt:
We know that fringe width \(\beta = \cfrac { D \lambda } { d }\)

\(\therefore x = \cfrac { L \lambda } { d } \Rightarrow \lambda = \cfrac { x d } { L }\)

quest_title: A transverse wave is described by the equation \(y = y_{o} \sin 2\pi (ft-x/\lambda)\). If the maximum particle velocity is equal to four times the wave velocity then which of the following is true.
explanation_txt:
\(y=y_{0} \sin 2 \pi[f t-x / \lambda]\)

Wave welocity \(v=t \lambda\)

Maximum particle velocity;

\(v_{p}=A(v)=y_{0} \times 2 \pi f\)

Given that, \(v_{p}=4 \times v\)

\(\begin{aligned} y_{0} & \times 2 \pi f=4 \times f \lambda \\ \therefore \lambda &=\cfrac{\pi y_{o}}{2} \end{aligned}\)
question_plain_title: A transverse wave is described by the equation . If the maximum particle velocity is equal to four times the wave velocity then which of the following is true.
explanation_plain_text:
Wave welocity

Maximum particle velocity;

Given that,
ans1_plain_text: = y/4
ans2_plain_text: = y/2
ans3_plain_text: = y
ans4_plain_text: = 2y

quest_title: Cathode rays are similar to visible light rays in that
ans1_txt: They both can be deflected by electric and magnetic fields.
ans2_txt: They both have a definite magnitude of wavelength.
ans3_txt: They both can ionize a gas through which they pass.
ans4_txt: They both can expose a photographic plate.
explanation_txt:
Light consists of photons and cathode rays consists of electrons.

Light rays are electromagnetic rays which do not deflect in electric and magnetic field but cathode rays (electrons) do. Their wavelength is also different. Light rays not necessarily ionize gas through which they pass unlike cathode rays.

However, both expose the photographic plate.
question_plain_title: Cathode rays are similar to visible light rays in that
explanation_plain_text:
Light consists of photons and cathode rays consists of electrons.

Light rays are electromagnetic rays which do not deflect in electric and magnetic field but cathode rays (electrons) do. Their wavelength is also different. Light rays not necessarily ionize gas through which they pass unlike cathode rays.

However, both expose the photographic plate.
ans1_plain_text: They both can be deflected by electric and magnetic fields.
ans2_plain_text: They both have a definite magnitude of wavelength.
ans3_plain_text: They both can ionize a gas through which they pass.
ans4_plain_text: They both can expose a photographic plate.

\(\therefore r \propto p\)

quest_title: In inductive coil has a resistance of 100 \(\Omega\). When an AC signal of frequency 1000 Hz is fed to the coil, the applied voltage leads the current by 45\(^\circ\). What is the inductance of the coil?
explanation_txt:
\(\tan \theta=\cfrac{X_{L}}{R}=\cfrac{\omega L}{R} \)
\(L=\cfrac{R \tan \theta}{\omega}=\cfrac{100 \times \tan 45^{\circ}}{2 \pi \times 1000} \approx 16 \mathrm{mH} \)

quest_title: \(\text{A\({}_{1}\)g}\) of an element give \(\text{A\({}_{2}\)}\) g of its chloride: the equivalent mass of the element is:
explanation_txt:
Mass of chlorine in the chloride = \(A_2-A_1\)

\(A_2-A_1\) gram of chlorine combines with \(A_1\) gram of element

1 gram of chlorine combines with \(\cfrac{A_1}{A_2-A_1}\) gram of the element.

Equivalent mass of chlorine = 35.5

\(\therefore\) 35.5 gram of chlorine combines with \(\cfrac{A_1}{A_2-A_1}\times 35.5\) gram of the element.

And as always 1 equivalent weight of an element combines with 1 equivalent weight of that compound.

Hence, equivalent weight of the element = \(\cfrac{A_1}{A_2-A_1}\times 35.5\)

When the initial pressure of \(\mathrm{XY}_{2}\) is \(0.4 \mathrm{atm}\), the total equilibrium pressure after dissociation is \(0.55 \mathrm{atm}\), the equilibrium constant \(\mathrm{K}_{\mathrm{p}}\) for the system assuming that the volume remains unchanged;
explanation_txt:

\(\begin{matrix} & XY_2 & \rightleftharpoons & XY &+& Y \\ P_0: & 0.4 & & 0 & & 0 \\ P : & 0.4-P & & P & & P \end{matrix}\)

By given,

\(0.4-P+2P=0.55 \\ \Rightarrow P = 0.15\)

\(K_p = \cfrac{0.15 \times 0.15}{0.4-0.15} = 0.09\)

quest_title: The general value of \(\theta \) satisfying the equation \(\tan \theta +\tan \left(\cfrac{\pi }{2} -\theta \right)=2\), is :
explanation_txt:
\[ \tan \theta +\cfrac{1}{\tan \theta } =2 \]

\[ \Rightarrow \tan ^{2} \theta -2\tan \theta +1=0\]

\[\Rightarrow \tan \theta =1=\tan \cfrac{\pi }{4} \]

\[ \Rightarrow \theta =n\pi +\cfrac{\pi }{4} .\]

quest_title: The oxidation state of zinc can be
explanation_txt:
The electronic configuration of zinc is: \( 1s^2,2s^2,2p^6,3s^2,3p^64s^23d^{10} \)

Since the \(d\) orbital is completely filled, it can exhibit only one oxidation state, \(+2\) [by losing 2 electrons from 4s orbital]

For this reason, Zn is called 'non-typical transition metal'.
question_plain_title: The oxidation state of zinc can be
explanation_plain_text:
The electronic configuration of zinc is:

Since the orbital is completely filled, it can exhibit only one oxidation state, [by losing 2 electrons from 4s orbital]

For this reason, Zn is called 'non-typical transition metal'.

quest_title: Which of the following metal doesn't react with copper sulphate?
explanation_txt:
Silver is less electropositive than copper and hence can't displace Cu from \(CuSO_4\).

Electrochemical series of some metals is given here:

Order Metal (Symbol) Electropositive than hydrogen
1 K Yes
2 Na Yes
3 Ca Yes
4 Mg Yes
5 Al Yes
6 Zn Yes
7 Fe Yes
8 Sn Yes
9 Pb Yes
10 Cu No
11 Hg No
12 Ag No
13 Au No

quest_title: If \(X=\{ 4^{n} -3n-1:n\in N\} \) and \(Y=\{ 9(n-1):n\in N\} ,\) then \(X\cup Y\) is equal to
explanation_txt:
Writing the sets in listing form:

\( X = \{0,9,54,243,1008,...\} \\ Y = \{0,9,18,27,36,45,54,...\}\)

It is evident that all the elements of \(X\) are multiples of \(9\) and hence belong to \(Y\).

i.e, \( X \subset Y \) which implies \( X \cup Y = Y \)

quest_title: The real values of \(x\) and \(y\) for which the equation is \(( x + i y ) ( 2 - 3 i ) = 4 + i\) is satisfied, are
explanation_txt:
Equation \(( x + i y ) ( 2 - 3 i ) = 4 + i\)

\(\Rightarrow ( 2 x + 3 y ) + i ( - 3 x + 2 y ) = 4 + i\)

Equating real and imaginary parts, we get

\(2 x + 3 y = 4\) ......(i)

\(- 3 x + 2 y = 1\)......(ii)

From (i) and (ii), we get \(x = \cfrac { 5 } { 13 } , y = \cfrac { 14 } { 13 }\)

[ \(x + i y = \cfrac { 4 + i } { 2 - 3 i } = \cfrac { ( 4 + i ) ( 2 + 3 i ) } { 13 } = \cfrac { 5 } { 13 } + \cfrac { 14 } { 13 } i\) ]

quest_title: If the position vectors of the vertices of a triangle be \( 5 \mathbf { i } + 7 \mathbf { j } + 4 \mathbf { k } , \quad 4 \mathbf { i } + 5 \mathbf { j } + 6 \mathbf { k }\) and \(6 \mathbf { i } + 6 \mathbf { j } + 8 \mathbf { k }\) then the triangle is
explanation_txt:
Let

\(A = (5,7,4) \\ B = (4,5,6) \\ C = (6,6,8) \)

\(\mathbf { a } = 2 \mathbf { i } + \mathbf { j } + 2 \mathbf { k } \Rightarrow | a | = \sqrt { 4 + 1 + 4 } = \sqrt { 9 }\)
\(\mathbf { b } = - \mathbf { i } + \mathbf { j } - 4 \mathbf { k } \Rightarrow b | = \sqrt { 1 + 1 + 16 } = \sqrt { 18 }\)
\(\mathbf { c } = - \mathbf { i } - 2 \mathbf { j } + 2 \mathbf { k } \Rightarrow | c | = \sqrt { 1 + 4 + 4 } = \sqrt { 9 }\)
\(| \mathbf { a } | = | \mathbf { c } |\) and also, \( \mathbf { b } ^ { 2 } = \sqrt { \mathbf { a } ^ { 2} + \mathbf { c } ^ { 2 } } .\)
Hence it is isosceles and right angled triangle.

quest_title: If the vectors \(i-3j+2k\), \(-i+2j\) represents the diagonals of a parallelogram, then its area will be
explanation_txt:
Let \(a=i-3j+2k,\) \(b=-i+2j\) \[\Rightarrow a\times b=\left|\begin{array}{ccc} {i} & {j} & {k} \\ {1} & {-3} & {2} \\ {-1} & {2} & {0} \end{array}\right|=-4i-2j-k\]

Hence area is equal to \(\cfrac{1}{2} |a\times b|\, =\cfrac{\sqrt{21} }{2} .\)

quest_title: The area bounded by \(y=\log \, x\), \(y=\sin ^{4} \pi x\) and \(x=0\), is:
explanation_txt:
The curve \( y = \log x \) passes through \( (1,0) \) and is asymptotic about the line \(x=0\).

Similarly, the curve \( y = \sin ^{4} \pi x \) passes through \( (0,0) \) and \( (1,0) \).

These curve don't intersect except at \( (1,0) \).

We are asked the area made with \(Y\) axis.

This is equivalent to the integration: [see graph]

\[ \begin{align} A & = \int_0^1 \sin ^4 (\pi x) dx + \int_{- \infty}^ 0 e^{y} dy \\ \\ & = I_1 + e^0 - e^{-\infty} = I_1 + 1 \end{align} \]

For \(I_1:\)

\[ \begin{align} I_1 & = \int_0^1 \sin^2(\pi x) (1 - \cos^2 (\pi x) ) dx \\ & =\cfrac{1}{2} \int_0^1 (1 - \cos 2 \pi x)dx - \cfrac{1}{8} \int_0^1 (1 - \cos 4 \pi x) dx \\ & =\cfrac{1}{2} \left[ x - \cfrac{\sin 2 \pi x}{2 \pi} \right]_0^1 - \cfrac{1}{8} \left[x - \cfrac{ \sin 4 \pi x}{4 \pi} \right] _0^1 \\ & = \cfrac{1}{2} - \cfrac{1}{8} \quad \quad \left( \because \sin(n \pi ) = 0 \right) \\ & = \cfrac{3}{8} \end{align} \]

And,

\[ A = I_1 + 1 = 1 + \cfrac{3}{8} = \cfrac{11}{8} \]

quest_title: The unit of Stefan's constant is
explanation_txt:
According to Stefan's Law,

\(E=\sigma A{T}^{4}\Rightarrow \sigma=\cfrac{E}{A{T}^{4}}\)

\(\therefore \sigma=\cfrac{Watt}{{m}^{2}*{T}^{4}}=W{m}^{-2}{K}^{-4}\)

The coefficient of friction between block \(\text{A}\) and \(\text{B}\) is 0.2 and 40 N force is applied on \(\text{A}\), then acceleration of \(\text{A}\) is
explanation_txt:
\(F-\mu_{s} m_{B} g=m_{A} a\)

\(\therefore a=\cfrac{40-0.2 \times 5 \times 10}{10}=\cfrac{30}{10}=3 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}\)

quest_title: The gas of rms speed 1.9\(\times\)10\({}^{3}\)m/s contain 6.8\(\times\)10\({}^{21}\) molecules/m\({}^{3}\) then pressure of gas of molar mass 2g is
explanation_txt:
\(\begin{aligned} \mathrm{P} &=\cfrac{1}{3} \mathrm{nm} \overline{C^{2}} \\ &=\cfrac{1}{3} \times 6.8 \times 10^{21} \times \cfrac{2 \times 10^{-3}}{6.023 \times 10^{23}} \times(1900)^{2} \end{aligned}\)

\(=27 \mathrm{N} / \mathrm{m}^{2}\)

\(\begin{array}{l}{\mathrm{P}=\rho \mathrm{gh}} \\ {\mathrm{h}=\cfrac{P}{\rho g}=\cfrac{27}{13600 \times 10}=0.2 \mathrm{mm} \text { of Hg }}\end{array}\)

quest_title: A achromatic combination is made with a lens of focal length \(f\) and dispersive power \(\omega \) with a lens having dispersive power of \(2\omega \). The focal length of second will be
explanation_txt:
For achromatic combination,

\(\cfrac{\omega}{f}+\cfrac{\omega '}{f'}=0\)

\(\Rightarrow \cfrac{\omega}{f}+\cfrac{2\omega}{f'}=0\)

\(\Rightarrow \cfrac{2\omega}{f'}=-\cfrac{\omega}{f}\)

\(\Rightarrow f'=-2f\)

quest_title: When light is incident on a doubly refracting crystal, two refracted rays-ordinary ray (O-ray) and extra ordinary ray (E-ray) are produced. Then
ans1_txt: Both O-ray and E-ray are polarized perpendicular to the plane of incidence
ans2_txt: Both O-ray and E-ray are polarized in the plane of incidence
ans3_txt: E-ray is polarized perpendicular to the plane of incidence and O-ray in the plane of incidence
ans4_txt: E-ray is polarized in the plane of incidence and O-ray perpendicular to the plane of incidence
explanation_txt:
The different angles of refraction for the two polarization components are shown in the figure with the optic axis along the surface and perpendicular to the plane of incidence. The angle of refraction is different for ordinary ray (O ray) in this case, having its polarization perpendicular to the optic axis and the extraordinary ray (E ray) with a polarization component along the optic axis.

Source: Wikipedia
question_plain_title: When light is incident on a doubly refracting crystal, two refracted rays-ordinary ray (O-ray) and extra ordinary ray (E-ray) are produced. Then
explanation_plain_text:
The different angles of refraction for the two polarization components are shown in the figure with the optic axis along the surface and perpendicular to the plane of incidence. The angle of refraction is different for ordinary ray (O ray) in this case, having its polarization perpendicular to the optic axis and the extraordinary ray (E ray) with a polarization component along the optic axis.

Source: Wikipedia
ans1_plain_text: Both O-ray and E-ray are polarized perpendicular to the plane of incidence
ans2_plain_text: Both O-ray and E-ray are polarized in the plane of incidence
ans3_plain_text: E-ray is polarized perpendicular to the plane of incidence and O-ray in the plane of incidence
ans4_plain_text: E-ray is polarized in the plane of incidence and O-ray perpendicular to the plane of incidence

explanation_txt:

Note : Mixed salt is an inorganic compound that consists of a fixed proportion of two salts, often sharing either a common cation or common anion.

quest_title: Four dice (six faced) are rolled. The number of possible outcomes in which at least one die shows 2 is
explanation_txt:
The number of possible outcomes with 2 on at least one die = (The total number of outcomes) - (The number of outcomes in which 2 does not appear on any die)

\(=6^{4} -5^{4} =1296-625=671\).
